author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: U.S. Government to Begin Accepting Requests for Free Covid Tests Next Week
description: The tests will take up to 12 days to arrive, which may be after the peak of the current surge of cases in some parts of the country.
content: WASHINGTON — Americans will be able to request free rapid coronavirus tests from the federal government beginning on Wednesday, but the tests will take seven to 12 days to arrive, senior Biden administration officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Jillette
title: The Sublime Beauty of My Friend Bob Saget’s Filthy Comedy
description: How I explained his offensive jokes to my horrified kids.
content: My children are teenagers, ages 15 and 16, and they know the comic Bob Saget was my friend. They know he died earlier this week, and that I’m grieving. They want to comfort me. But when they saw clips of Bob on the internet, making hard-core jokes about pedophilia and incest, they were offended. They thought my friend must have been a bad person, and it was hard for them to understand how I could have loved him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democrats Face a Dilemma on Voting: Compromise or Keep Pressing?
description: With their broad voting rights push nearing a dead end, Democrats must soon decide whether to embrace a far narrower bipartisan effort to protect vote counting and administration.
content: WASHINGTON — With their drive to secure far-reaching voting rights legislation nearing a dead end, Senate Democrats face a decision they had hoped to avoid: Should they embrace a much narrower, bipartisan effort to safeguard the vote-counting process, or continue what increasingly looks like a doomed push to protect access to the ballot box?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Troy Closson
title: Firefighters Continue to Battle Large Blaze at Passaic Chemical Plant
description: Firefighters were still working to bring the fire under control on Saturday morning 14 hours after it erupted, but officials said residents did not need to evacuate.
content: Firefighters continued to battle a large blaze on Saturday morning at a chemical plant in Passaic, N.J., more than 14 hours after it erupted, sending towering flames into the sky and clouds of smoke wafting through the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Underwater Volcano Erupts, Setting Off Tsunami Warnings Across Pacific
description: The volcano erupted near the remote island nation of Tonga, triggering a chain of warnings and causing strong waves as far away as the United States.
content: An underwater volcano erupted on Saturday near the remote Pacific nation of Tonga, triggering tsunami warnings across the Pacific and for the West Coast of the United States, and causing strong waves and currents in many coastal areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Trump Rally Underscores G.O.P. Tension Over How to Win in 2022
description: Donald Trump’s rally in Arizona on Saturday featured a host of election deniers. His involvement in state races and his inability to let go of his 2020 loss worries many Republicans.
content: FLORENCE, Ariz. — Former President Donald J. Trump returned on Saturday to Arizona, a cradle of his political movement, to headline a rally in the desert that was a striking testament to how he has elevated fringe beliefs and the politicians who spread them — even as other Republicans openly worry that voters will ultimately punish their party for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch and Reed Abelson
title: Hospitals Confront the Fallout From Supreme Court Ruling on Vaccine Mandate
description: They could face more staff shortages, and workers and facilities could feel caught between opposing state and federal policies.
content: Just days after the Supreme Court’s decision about requiring health care workers to be vaccinated, the nation’s health care systems braced for the possibility of some resistance and more staff shortages — particularly in the states that banned mandates or had none.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: What the Bengals’ and Bills’ Wins Mean for the Divisional Round
description: The No. 4-seeded Bengals beat the No. 5-seeded Raiders Saturday, Cincinnati’s first playoff win in 31 years, and the Bills vanquished the Patriots in the night game in Buffalo.
content: The Cincinnati Bengals beat the Las Vegas Raiders for the second time this season, 26-19, and the Buffalo Bills rolled over the New England Patriots, 47-17, as better-seeded teams held on to advance to the divisional round of the N.F.L. playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Paul Carter Harrison, Whose Ideas Shaped Black Theater, Dies at 85
description: In his essays and plays, he provided a framework that linked playwrights like August Wilson to African rituals and mythologies.
content: Paul Carter Harrison, a playwright and scholar who in books, essays and award-winning plays provided a theoretical structure for the Black performing arts, linking works by writers like August Wilson to a deeply rooted structure of African ritual and myth, died on Dec. 27 in Atlanta. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Here’s Some (Slightly) Less Worrisome Covid-and-Kids News
description: Hold off before freaking out about that new C.D.C. diabetes study.
content: I got a lot of feedback on my last newsletter, about how parents of children under 5 are struggling in a variety of ways with the pandemic’s current Omicron wave. Some readers felt I didn’t adequately underscore the point that statistically speaking, the risk of serious illness and death for children with Covid is very slim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Andy Newman
title: Woman Dies After Being Pushed Onto Subway Tracks in Times Square
description: The police said Michelle Go, 40, of Manhattan, was shoved in front of an R train as it approached a 42nd Street platform in Manhattan on Saturday morning.
content: In a horrifying instant, a man walked up to a 40-year-old woman waiting for the subway in Times Square on Saturday morning and shoved her to the tracks as a train screeched into the station, killing her, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Joe B. Hall, Longtime Kentucky Men’s Basketball Coach, Dies at 93
description: Following Adolph Rupp, one of the greatest college coaches of all time, was a challenge. Hall rose to the occasion, taking the team to the Final Four three times.
content: When Joe B. Hall became the University of Kentucky men’s basketball coach in 1972, he had no head coaching experience at a major college and he was succeeding one of the game’s legendary figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Americans are just learning what people in East Asia already know about masks.
description: In some parts of Asia, surgical masks became commonplace during SARS epidemic of 2002-2003.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention conceded in an announcement on Friday that cloth masks do not protect against the coronavirus as effectively as surgical masks or respirators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Months After an Explosion, a Town Is Deserted and Without Answers
description: Hundreds of people in Wheatley, Ontario, are still out of their homes four months after a gas leak blew up three buildings in the town’s center.
content: It’s not a disaster scene like those left by the recent destructive flooding or wildfires in British Columbia. But the effects of an explosion last August in Wheatley, Ontario, have similarly upended the lives of hundreds of people in that town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Census Memo Cites ‘Unprecedented’ Meddling by Trump Administration
description: Newly released documents show that top career officials at the Census Bureau had drafted a list of complaints about political interference in the 2020 count.
content: WASHINGTON — A newly disclosed memorandum citing “unprecedented” meddling by the Trump administration in the 2020 census and circulated among top Census Bureau officials indicates how strongly they sought to resist efforts by the administration to manipulate the count for Republican political gain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Pay Your Power Bill, Myanmar Soldiers Say, or Pay With Your Life
description: Facing a huge loss of revenue amid economic turmoil, the military has sent soldiers to act as debt collectors.
content: The schoolteacher had just gotten out of bed when four Myanmar army soldiers pounded on her door. Her electricity payment was overdue, they said, and ordered her to pay it immediately at the government power company office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonia Purnell
title: Boris Johnson Has Survived Many Scandals. This One Is Different.
description: What might seem like an overblown reaction to a gathering in a garden — as opposed to, say, a violent insurrection — could well have historic repercussions.
content: When Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressed British lawmakers in a febrile Parliament on Wednesday, he appeared to raise his eyes to the heavens for a split moment as if to seek rescue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Building a Better Meatpacking Industry
description: Instead of breaking up the big meatpacking companies, the Biden administration is supporting the creation of  rivals.
content: MARCUS, Iowa — The last time the federal government decided that a few big meatpacking firms were abusing their market power, in the early 1920s, it chopped those companies into smaller pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: A Library the Internet Can’t Get Enough Of
description: Why does this image keep resurfacing on social media?
content: On the first Tuesday of the year, the author and political activist Don Winslow tweeted a photograph of an avid reader’s dream library. Bathed in the buttery glow of three table lamps, almost every surface of the room is covered with books. There are books on the tables, books stacked on mahogany ladders, and books atop still more books lining the shelves of the room. “I hope you see the beauty in this that I do,” Mr. Winslow wrote in the tweet, which has been acknowledged with 32,800 hearts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: In a First, Ohio Moves to Put Body Cameras on Guards in Every Prison
description: The state is distributing 5,100 new body-worn cameras, the most extensive commitment of any state as corrections facilities across the country push for better surveillance.
content: Thousands of Ohio prison guards will begin wearing body cameras for the first time this year, bringing more transparency inside prison walls at a time when the coronavirus pandemic and guard shortages are making many prisons more dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Spiders, Archaeology and Brain Confetti
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: ¡Feliz Año Nuevo! Doesn’t it feel fabulous to be an entirely reborn person with flawless habits, unbroken willpower and a rose-tinted view of the future? Oh, that doesn’t describe you? Me neither.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Eye-Opening Declaration?
description: Prepare to double up on takes when you take on Sam Ezersky’s Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s always nice to see Sam Ezersky’s name on a daily grid. I worry about his losing his mojo after his 15,000th day of being a piñata for fervent Spelling Bee solvers. (“Phaeton,” they whisper in unison, as they wildly swing their sticks. “Figgy.”) Unsurprising elements in an Ezersky puzzle include football trivia; an underpinning of inventive debuts; earnest references to 21st-century fads, treated as if they were sacred institutional canon; sneaky but always good-natured jokes. Check, check, check and check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Michael Parks, Reporter Who Rose to Lead The Los Angeles Times, Dies at 78
description: A Pulitzer winner, he covered the Vietnam War, the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of apartheid in South Africa before running The Times’s newsroom.
content: Michael Parks, a Pulitzer-Prize-winning foreign correspondent for The Los Angeles Times who went on to become the top editor at the paper, one of the nation’s largest metropolitan dailies, died on Jan. 8 at a hospital in Pasadena, Calif. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: ‘Attempted Security Threat’ Disables Software at Some New York Schools
description: The outage in a platform used by teachers and students has caused another disruption for a system that has had its share amid the pandemic.
content: An online platform used in some New York City public schools has been out of service since last Saturday after a “security incident,” forcing teachers to rely on more traditional ways of recording grades, tracking attendance and contacting students and parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: One America News Will Be Dropped by DirecTV, a Major Distributor
description: The right-wing network has aired conspiracies about the 2020 election, last year’s Capitol riot and the safety of coronavirus vaccines.
content: The right-wing cable channel One America News Network — which has spread conspiracy theories about the 2020 election, the Jan. 6 Capitol riot and the safety of coronavirus vaccines — will be dropped by one of its largest television distributors later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: What is the impact on the U.S. right now?
description: Communities in California and other parts of the western United States were on alert Saturday after an undersea volcano erupted in the South Pacific, leading to powerful surges of water that inundated harbors and low-lying areas and left at least six people needing rescue.
content: Communities in California and other parts of the western United States were on alert Saturday after an undersea volcano erupted in the South Pacific, leading to powerful surges of water that inundated harbors and low-lying areas and left at least six people needing rescue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Yes, Alabama Dominates College Football. Get Over It.
description: When a team is this good, we should just enjoy it.
content: On Monday night, the Alabama Crimson Tide lost to the Georgia Bulldogs for the national championship in college football. Which was different from four years ago, when Alabama defeated Georgia for the title. Since 2010, Alabama has appeared in the title game nine times and won six of them. Since the College Football Playoff system was instituted in the 2014-2015 season, in part to produce a more competitive environment that would let the non-Alabamas of the world aim for a title, Alabama has competed in six title games and won three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: To Run or Not to Run? That’s the Midterm Question.
description: For members of Congress weighing if another run is worth the hassle, the time to decide is fast approaching.
content: It’s crunchtime in the campaign world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: 32 Years After Civil War, Mundane Moments Trigger Awful Memories
description: Cards. Candles. Sunsets. For this New York Times correspondent and other children of Beirut in the 1980s, traumatic reminders of the war are still there in everyday activities.
content: When you’re a child, how do you get through a war?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: The Downfall of Prince Andrew: Here’s What You Need to Know
description: After a New York judge ruled that a civil suit against the prince could move forward, he was stripped of his military titles. What happens now?
content: He was a dashing helicopter pilot and war hero, who captivated millions of Britons during the Falkland Islands war. Royal watchers liked to say he was a favorite of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: CVS and Walgreens temporarily shut some stores as Omicron cases soar.
description: Both chains said the vast majority of their stores will remain open.
content: CVS and Walgreens, two of the biggest pharmacy chains in the United States, are temporarily closing some stores this weekend because of staff shortages complicated by the soaring number of people infected with the Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: If My Roommate Stops Paying Rent, Am I on the Hook for It?
description: Just because renters split the cost of living doesn’t mean they split the responsibility of paying the total that is owed to the landlord.
content: Q: In 2020, I lived in a three-bedroom apartment with two roommates. We all signed the lease, but each of us paid portions of the security deposit directly to the landlord. We also the paid the rent in three separate checks. During the pandemic, one roommate moved back home and stopped paying rent, while the other roommate and I stayed through the end of the lease and paid our portions of the rent on time. When we moved out at the end of the lease, we left the apartment in good condition, but when it came time to get our security deposit back, the landlord withheld the money on account of our former roommate. Can the landlord do this? What are my legal options to recoup my portion of that money?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Let Innocent Afghans Have Their Money
description: Afghanistan is on the verge of collapse.
content: Malnourished children with withered arms have been arriving at clinics in Afghanistan for months now. Although the markets are full of food, too many people lack the money to buy it. Since U.S. forces withdrew and the Taliban seized control in August, prices have skyrocketed. Even those people lucky enough to have savings in the bank have to line up for hours to withdraw a small fraction of it. Banks are so low on cash that they have placed a limit on withdrawals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Medical professionals urge Spotify to crack down on Covid misinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: When It Comes to Living With Covid, Businesses Are on Their Own
description: With no uniform national approach in sight, it’s up to chief executives to decide when and how to pursue a “new normal.”
content: Companies looking for an official rule book on pandemic precautions will be disappointed. The Biden administration’s nationwide coronavirus vaccine mandate has been overturned. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is facing criticism for its shifting guidance on isolation times. And just as cases surge to record levels, tests are scarce — and may not always be effective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Kramer
title: Rosa Lee Hawkins, Youngest Member of the Dixie Cups, Dies at 76
description: The singing group’s debut single, “Chapel of Love,” rose to the top of the charts in 1964, displacing the Beatles’ “Love Me Do.”
content: Rosa Lee Hawkins, the youngest member of the musical trio the Dixie Cups, whose hit single “Chapel of Love” reached No. 1 on the Billboard 100 in 1964, died on Tuesday in Tampa, Fla. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Desperately in Demand This Pandemic Winter: Snowplow Operators
description: An upheaval in the labor force has affected the transportation sector, creating shortages of snow-clearing professionals as winter storms pummel the United States.
content: As storms sweep across the United States, officials are having to contend with twin challenges this pandemic winter: too much snow, and not enough drivers to get rid of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Steinberger
title: Novak Djokovic, a Master on the Court, Keeps Making Errors Off It
description: Djokovic, the Serbian tennis star, is at the center of some of the most divisive debates of the pandemic: Individual versus community, science versus quackery.
content: In April 2020, with the pro tennis tour suspended because of the coronavirus pandemic, Novak Djokovic took part in a Facebook Live chat with some fellow Serbian athletes. During their conversation, Djokovic, famous for his punishing training regimen, abstemious diet and fondness for New Age beliefs, said he was “opposed to vaccination” and “wouldn’t want to be forced by someone to take a vaccine in order to be able to travel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: What the Omicron Wave Looks Like at One Brooklyn E.R.
description: The nature of this variant, combined with widespread vaccine use, may make it seem less severe in some ways than earlier ones. It doesn’t always feel like that here.
content: A young man poked his head out of an isolation room and demanded, not for the first time, to know the Covid-19 test result he was waiting for. He kept asking until Natasha Williams looked up.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Dozens on Trial in Cuba After Harsh Crackdown Over a Wave of Protests
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 15, 2022.
content: “What reigns here is an empire of fear. The repression here doesn’t kill directly, but forces you to choose between prison and exile.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Kellen Browning
title: Crypto Enthusiasts Meet Their Match: Angry Gamers
description: Game publishers are offering NFTs, but skeptical gamers smell a moneymaking scheme and are fighting back.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Christian Lantz has played S.T.A.L.K.E.R., a first-person shooter game set in a post-apocalyptic Ukraine that became a cult hit for its immersive role playing. So when the 18-year-old high schooler heard a sequel was coming this year, he knew he had to buy it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Emily Cochrane
title: Frustrated Democrats Call for ‘Reset’ Ahead of Midterm Elections
description: Democrats already were expecting a rough election year. But their struggle to advance priorities has some calling for a course correction.
content: WASHINGTON — With the White House legislative agenda in shambles less than a year before the midterm elections, Democrats are sounding alarms that their party could face even deeper losses than anticipated without a major shift in strategy led by the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Playing the Hits
description: Derrick Niederman’s puzzle will get your toes tapping, eventually!
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is what’s called a crossover episode on television, and I love it: Derrick Niederman, a mathematics professor at the College of Charleston, S.C., has woven a Puns and Anagrams puzzle into a Sunday grid and created a fun, twisty challenge. Mr. Niederman specializes in these two puzzle forms; this is his 12th daily grid for The New York Times, all of them Sundays, and he has also constructed some fabulous variety puzzles. The print introduction for this grid recommends a puzzle of his from last year, a “Two-for-One Crossword,” that you should tackle next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata and Benjamin Mueller
title: Halting Progress and Happy Accidents: How mRNA Vaccines Were Made
description: The stunning Covid vaccines manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna drew upon long-buried discoveries made in the hopes of ending past epidemics.
content: Thousands of miles from Dr. Barney Graham’s lab in Bethesda, Md., a frightening new coronavirus had jumped from camels to humans in the Middle East, killing one out of every three people infected. An expert on the world’s most intractable viruses, Dr. Graham had been working for months to develop a vaccine, but had gotten nowhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Says It Shut Down Notorious Hacker Group at U.S. Request
description: Moscow said the ransomware group REvil “ceased to exist” after raids and arrests. It is not clear if the operation will ease tensions with Washington.
content: MOSCOW — Russia’s main security agency said on Friday that at the request of the United States government it had dismantled REvil, one of the most aggressive ransomware crime groups attacking Western targets, and arrested some of its members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Novak Djokovic’s Fight to Stay in Australia Lives Another Day
description: A federal court judge scheduled a Sunday hearing to address the unvaccinated tennis star’s Australian visa revocation. The Australian Open begins on Monday.
content: Novak Djokovic, the top men’s tennis player in the world, was detained on Saturday by border authorities in Australia, the latest turn in a legal dispute over his travel visa that has drawn interest around the world and inflamed tensions during a rapidly spreading coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: With Voting Bills Dead, Democrats Face Costly Fight to Overcome G.O.P. Curbs
description: Party officials now say they are resigned to spending and organizing their way around the new voting restrictions passed in Republican-controlled states.
content: With the door slammed shut this week on federal legislation to create new protections for access to voting, Democrats face an electoral landscape in which they will need to spend heavily to register and mobilize voters if they are to overcome the hodgepodge of new voting restrictions enacted by Republicans across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: As the Australian Open Nears, There Seems to Be Only One Story
description: With just days to go before the start of the tournament, some players felt that the Novak Djokovic situation was overshadowing everything else.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — One by one, some of the world’s greatest tennis players took off their masks on Saturday for a day of news conferences, but they did not necessarily let their guards down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Chris Evert, Tennis Hall of Famer, Says She Has Ovarian Cancer
description: The early-stage cancer was detected after a preventive hysterectomy, and it has not spread elsewhere in her body, according to ESPN.
content: The former tennis star Chris Evert, an 18-time Grand Slam singles champion, has an early form of ovarian cancer, she said Friday in a story posted on ESPN.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Where is Novak Djokovic?
description: The tennis star went into immigration detention on Saturday as he awaited his next hearing. News outlets said he was taken to a Melbourne hotel.
content: Novak Djokovic was taken into custody on Saturday by immigration officials as he fought the Australian government’s efforts to deport him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Erik Fisher
title: It’s Misleading to Call Addiction a Disease
description: The view that addiction is a disease makes it an individual problem. That’s dangerous.
content: In 2010, a little more than a year after graduating from medical school, I was admitted to a psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital after a drinking and Adderall binge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Towers Rise Over London’s Brick Lane, Clouding Its Future
description: Luxury developments and rising rents have ignited concerns about gentrification and displacement in a district that has long been a sanctuary for minority communities.
content: LONDON — Ornate English and Bengali typography adorns the signs of Taj Stores, one of the oldest Bangladeshi-run supermarkets in the Brick Lane neighborhood of East London. The signs evoke a part of the area’s past, when it became known as “Banglatown,” and eventually home to the largest Bangladeshi community in Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Terry Teachout, Arts Critic With a Wide Range, Is Dead at 65
description: He called himself a “well-informed amateur,” and he wrote about everything from bluegrass to ballet.
content: Terry Teachout, a cultural critic who, in his columns for The Wall Street Journal, The Daily News and other publications, brought his all-encompassing intellect to bear on Broadway, ballet, bluegrass and practically every art form in between, died on Thursday at the home of a friend in Smithtown, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Police Presentation in Portland Celebrated Violence Against Protesters
description: Training materials released by the Oregon city included a meme that mocked protesters as dirty hippies and suggested they would be left “stitched and bandaged.”
content: A slide show designed to train officers in Portland, Ore., on methods of policing protests concluded with a message that celebrated the use of violence against demonstrators, suggesting they would end up “stitched and bandaged,” according to records released by the city on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Michaels and Jordan Barab
title: OSHA Can Do More to Protect Americans From Covid-19
description: The Supreme Court’s decision on vaccine mandates leaves the door open for a new strategy to protect workers.
content: The Supreme Court’s decision on Thursday to block the Occupational Safety and Health Administration from requiring large employers to make sure that their workers are either vaccinated against the coronavirus or masked at work and tested weekly was a setback for America’s efforts to stop the pandemic. The six Republican-appointed justices are helping to prolong the pandemic, endanger workers and extend the labor shortage that has disrupted the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Is Joe Biden Thinking?
description: The strange strategy of a staggering presidency.
content: I’ve been trying to imagine some kind of strategic vision behind the Biden administration’s recent decision making — the strange pivot from the stalled-out Build Back Better negotiations to election reform theatrics, in which a president with miserable approval ratings managed to advertise his own political weakness and alienate potential negotiating partners, all in the service of legislation remote from most Americans’ immediate concerns and unlikely to address the genuine problems in the system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Marine Le Pen, Kicking Off Her Campaign, Tries to Embody Credibility
description: Ms. Le Pen has bet that sanitizing her far-right party’s image will finally bear fruit in the run-up to France’s presidential election in April.
content: PARIS — Marine Le Pen has long used fiery rhetoric and hard-hitting proposals to fight her way to power in France. But for her third presidential bid, she has struck an unusual tone: serenity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: More Mojo, Joe!
description: Less Senate bean soup, more affordable meat.
content: WASHINGTON — Poor Joe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Miller
title: Is Interning for an Influencer Worth It?
description: Young fans are messaging social media creators and entrepreneurs seeking experience. But the terms of the arrangements can vary widely.
content: In September 2020, a newly minted TikTok influencer named Audrey Peters secured her first brand partnership. An account called @Overheard asked her to recite snippets of outrageous conversation on her smartphone-filmed walks through Manhattan. But before long, Ms. Peters ran out of friends who were willing to trail her with a camera as she traipsed around the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles McDermid
title: Cambodia’s Internet May Soon Be Like China’s: State-Controlled
description: Under a new decree, all web traffic will be routed through a government portal. Rights groups say a crackdown on digital expression is about to get worse.
content: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The day Kea Sokun was arrested in Cambodia, four men in plainclothes showed up at his photography shop near Angkor Wat and carted him off to the police station. Mr. Kea Sokun, who is also a popular rapper, had released two songs on YouTube, and the men said they needed to know why he’d written them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Van Badham
title: Novak Djokovic Got the Boot. Australians Are Thrilled.
description: An otherwise skilled sportsman has recruited himself as a cack-handed symbol of everything presently enraging Australians.
content: Update: A panel of judges ruled on Sunday that Australia’s immigration minister was within his rights to cancel the tennis champion Novak Djokovic’s visa. The judges’ ruling is final; the Australian Open begins Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: 5 Surprising Things About Smell
description: Chuck McGinley studies life's stink. Here are some smelly tips.

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: The Uncertain Fate of a London Neighborhood
description: Brick Lane in East London is known for its many Bangladeshi-run businesses. But in the last few years, the neighborhood has drawn notice for its rapid gentrification.
content: Brick Lane in East London is known for its many Bangladeshi-run businesses. But in the last few years, the neighborhood has drawn notice for its rapid gentrification.

author: By Dakota santiago For The New York Times
title: Large Fire Erupts at a Chemical Plant in New Jersey
description: Crews battled a fire at a chemical plant in Passaic, N.J. No major injuries were reported.
content: Crews battled a fire at a chemical plant in Passaic, N.J. No major injuries were reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: The Charmed Life of Bruce Bozzi
description: He’s best friends with Andy Cohen and Sarah Jessica Parker, is married to super agent Bryan Lourd, and fancies himself a liquor mogul.
content: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Bruce B. Bozzi has always been one of the chosen ones, a Ken doll who runs with other Ken dolls. They’re smart, muscled and successful. They all seem to have been photographed on Barry Diller’s yacht. The Met Gala? Been there, done that, sat with Tom Ford.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 15, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 15, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a rejected bid in the Senate to impose sanctions on a Russian natural-gas pipeline misstated the tally of the vote. It was 55 to 44, not 55 to 43.
source.name: The New York Times
